references: In label restoration experiments, we compare ACB with state-of-the-art methods, including GradInversionÂ [7] and iDLGÂ [5], the latter also employed in GGIÂ [6]. As iDLG restores labels only when the batch size is 1, we fine-tune it to choose the label with the smallest Kğ¾K cross-entropy value as its y^^ğ‘¦\hat{y} for batch sizes of Kğ¾K. We use these strategies to reconstruct ImageNet 1K validation set image labels across various batch sizes. Images in each training batch are uniformly sampled, with the initial image index randomly chosen from 1 to 20K, and a uniform random number between 1 and 100 serving as the increment for the next image index. Label accuracy results are summarized in TableÂ II. Notably, ACB consistently outperforms iDLGÂ [5] and GradInversionÂ [7] across all batch sizes. Specifically, at a batch size of 2, ACB achieves 98.90% accuracy, surpassing iDLGÂ [5] by more than 20%, and outperforming GradInversionÂ [7] by over 11%.

references: To quantitatively assess performance, we employ four evaluation metrics: PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS, and MSE, and the metrics are summarized in TableÂ III. The findings consistently demonstrate that RAF-GI outperforms other strategies in terms of reconstruction quality. When Mâ€‹Iğ‘€ğ¼MI is significantly reduced from the original settings, DLG, GGI, and GradInversion exhibit poor x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} performance, with the models failing to converge effectively. In contrast, RAF-GI demonstrates faster model convergence and superior x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} quality. We present reconstructed results for the indexes of 5000, 7000, and 9000 images in FigureÂ 3 to illustrate the universality of the RAF-GI strategy.

references: We present the visual ablation experiment results in FigureÂ 9 and metrics for quantitative comparisons in TableÂ V. The optimal choice for reconstructing ground-truth images is observed in the final row (RAF-GI) in most cases. Without any regularization term (denoted as â€Noneâ€ in the second column of FigureÂ 9), the x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} exhibits poor performance with multiple subjects in the image and numerous noises. The introduction of RTâ€‹VsubscriptRğ‘‡ğ‘‰\textbf{R}_{TV} into the reconstruction strategy results in a significant reduction in noise and increased PSNR values. Addition of Rmâ€‹eâ€‹aâ€‹nsubscriptRğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘›\textbf{R}_{mean} to the reconstruction strategy eliminates multi-subjects and color distortions in x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x}, leading to higher SSIM values. Lastly, incorporating Rcâ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹nâ€‹ysubscriptRğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘¦\textbf{R}_{canny} corrects the image subject site, resulting in reduced values of LPIPS and MSE.

references: To assess the impact of x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} initialization on the final result, RAF-GI employs a random image as the initial x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} (RAF-GI-ran), while DLGÂ [4] and GGIÂ [6] use gray images as the initial x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} (DLG-gray, GGI-gray). Visual results and evaluation metrics for the final x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} are presented in FigureÂ 10 and TableÂ VI. Notably, comparisons between DLG and DLG-gray, GGI and GGI-gray, and RAF-GI-ran and RAF-GI highlight the superior reconstruction achieved when using gray images as the initial x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} (DLG-gray, GGI-gray, and RAF-GI). This underscores the critical role of the initial x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} in enhancing the quality of the final reconstruction. While GGI-gray shows better results in terms of PSNR and SSIM values in the second reconstructed image, it is important to note that the image subject position and visual effects may be compromised, revealing the limitations of relying solely on a single evaluation metric.

references: DLGÂ [4] and GGIÂ [6] employ distinct cost functions to quantify the difference between âˆ‡Wâ€²âˆ‡superscriptğ‘Šâ€²\nabla W^{\prime} and âˆ‡Wâˆ‡ğ‘Š\nabla W. Since GradInversionÂ [7] has already investigated the impact of the cost function on the quality of x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x}, we wonâ€™t experiment with the GradInversion transformation cost function in this study. We utilize various cost functions for DLG, GGI, and RAF-GI. Specifically, we consider DLG-cos\cos, GGI-â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}, and RAF-GI-â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}, modifying the cost function to cosine similarity and â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} distance. Visual results of reconstructed images and corresponding metrics are provided in FigureÂ 11 and TableÂ VII. Notably, cosine similarity exhibits a stronger tendency to generate high-quality x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x}. All strategies based on the cosine similarity cost function have higher values in PSNR and smaller LPIPS values than those with the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} distance cost function. This observation deviates from the findings in GradInversionÂ [7]. The discrepancy may be attributed to different regularization terms. In our experiments, the choice of the cost function significantly impacts the quality of x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x}, with cosine similarity showing a substantial advantage.
